awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation of US-based researchers in the European Set Theory Conference held in Turin, Italy on August 29 - September 2, 2022. This is the eighth in a biennial series of conferences that are organized by the European Set Theory Society. In addition to Americans and Europeans, the conference will be attended by researchers from around the world, including Japan, China, the Middle East,  and Latin and South America. It is a remarkable opportunity for students and junior researchers to meet and interact with established international experts.  The conference is also the venue for awarding the Hausdorff Prize, the premier honor for work in Set Theory. The grant supports travel for US-based junior researchers (graduate students and postdoctoral scholars) and a small number of the US-based invited plenary speakers. 

While set theory arose in connection with the foundations of mathematics, in the last two decades it has begun focusing on applications to neighboring areas of mathematics. These range from combinatorial methods applied to C*-algebras, to Ramsey theory, to topological dynamical systems. Two prominent senior set theorists, Saharon Shelah and Stevo Todorčević, are plenary speakers, and the US-based plenary speakers include two invited speakers from the 2022 International Congress of Mathematicians.

Conference web site: http://logicgroup.altervista.org/torino/ESTC2022/index2.php

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The European Set Theory Society the leading society in Europe for the Study of Set Theory and the foundations of mathematics.  It fosters important research and holds biennial meetings since 2007.  The most recent were in Cambridge in 2015, in Budapest in 2017, Vienna in 2019, and in Torino in 2022. (There was a one year delay due to Covid.) 

The grant provided financial support for 7 graduate students and 2 postdocs to attend the 2022 meeting. They spend 5 full days interacting with the speakers and other researchers, discussing mutual interests and learning about new mathematical projects to work on. 

The 2022 meeting was held from August 29 to September 2, 2022.  It had 15 invited speakers, covering a large portion of Set Theory.  There were 2 tutorials. 

The Hausdorff Medal was awarded at the Torino meeting to David Aspero and Ralf Schindler, for their work on Martin's Maximum and Woodin's Axiom (*).  

The topics of the talks were coloring and derived limits, infinite dimensional Ramsey theory, Inside out Set Theory, Abelian Polish Groups, dynamics of clopen semi-groups, translates of Borel sets, Descriptive Combinatorics, characterizations of supercompact and huge cardinals,  rotation equivalence and rigidity, MAD families, Adding Cohen Reals, Borel Asymptotic Dimension, Universally Baire Sets, A topological Basis Problem, and inner models from extended logics. 

The tutorials were about Prikry Forcing and Forcing Axioms and Determinacy.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2023
Modified by: Matthew D Foreman
